reviewText:
Assassin's Creed: Freedom Cry.

While not throwing stealth away completely, this game trades up stealth for some head on action sequences.
You play as Adewale, 15 years after the events of Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag.
Older, wiser and now a fully trained assassin. He even gets his own murder hood.

Much of the in game assets were from ACIV:BF so the graphics are more or less the same. Gameplay wise as well, but again more action than stealth really. And his attack animations, though not as fluid or graceful as i expected assassins would be, he has a sort of brutal flair that really defines him as an assassin. Not just Edward Kenway reskinned to be Adewale.

Weapons in Freedom Cry are different as they got rid of swords and daggers. You get machetes for Adewale instead. (This does not prevent you from picking up and using a sword from a slain enemy.)
No flintlock pistols, just a blunderbuss for you, Ade.
You still have your own pair of Hidden Blades of course.

The whole campaign itself is short and sweet. It left me wanting more from it, more of what happens to Adewale, more of what becomes of the liberated slaves and their resistance and more of what happened to the Assassins after Black Flag.
For a DLC turned standalone game, it has a lot more content than one would expect.
Honestly i thought it was just gonna be a bunch of uninspired self contained missions, but this totally blew me away.


I dare say Adewale was more fun to play with than Connor. But of course, that is my opinion.


Get it on sale if you feel that $15 is still too much. Get it however you can as it is a very good game and you won't really regret playing it.

reviewText: It’s unusual for Assassin’s Creed story DLC to feature someone who wasn’t the lead character of the main game. Since Assassin’s Creed IV’s story led Edward back to England, though, in order to maintain the Caribbean setting, Freedom Cry tells a tale of Edward’s charismatic quartermaster, Adéwalé, instead. Adéwalé is captain of his own ship now, and he’s a high-ranking member of the Brotherhood as he continues to fight the war against the Templars. Freedom Cry is, quite honestly, the most powerful tale the franchise has told. The Assassin-Templar war is nothing but set dressing that’s promptly shoved into the background to make way for a story about human perseverance, all while cleverly tying the Assassin’s Creed universe into the start of a movement that led to the largest slave revolt in history.The evils of racism and slavery are prevalent throughout and handled far better here than they were in Liberation or their all-too-brief mention in Assassin’s Creed III. Nearly everyone who isn’t a slave sees Adéwalé as an enemy, making even a casual walk through Port-au-Prince a nightmare—and quickly forcing him into combat should he attempt anything suspicious.This makes Freedom Cry surprisingly difficult at times, since almost the entire city is against you. The game subtly makes you aware that you’re having a harder time of things simply because of the color of your skin, and it feels wrong on so many levels. It’s a risky venture for the developers, but I think the message is clear. Besides the stellar storytelling, the game features the same great action for which the series is known, as well as twists on some Black Flag side missions that now revolve around the slavery theme. Instead of recruiting pirates for your crew, you free runaways, liberate slaves from the auction block, or break others out of prison cages.Freedom Cry does have some limitations that put a crimp on its value, though. The exploration and sheer scope of the world seen in the main game are completely gone, leaving you to race through the nine story missions with little incentive to wander from the predetermined path. And, sure, you can still go out to sea, but there’s really no point beyond a couple of mission parameters, since 90 percent of the action takes place within Port-au-Prince.Freedom Cry clearly takes a technical step backward from the accomplishment that was the world of Black Flag. Adéwalé steps brilliantly into the lead role, though. His story, short as it is, helps make up for the smaller world, and it’s enough for Assassin’s Creed fans to check out Freedom Cry if they’re even remotely interested.

reviewText:
You let out a cry of freedom as you return
home from work, dead tired.

It’s bad enough you’ve been juggling school
and a part-time job at the bookstore, in
addition to your growing relationship with
the beautiful Goth in the class, _Summer-Rain_.
She’s been arguing with you lately.

Logging in to Steam once more after dragging
your feet from the bath, you see a game
that you don’t seem to remember:

Assassin’s Creed: Freedom Cry.

You vaguely recall that it focused on the
supporting character, Adewale; from the
fourth title in the series, Black Flag, and it
was originally marketed as DLC before
becoming a standalone title.

Shrugging, you buy and soon install the game.
You try not to think about the things you
had to put up with throughout the week
in the back of your head; that idiot boss
you hate but you need your job more,
the school projects getting more mentally
demanding and _ Summer-Rain_ arguing
with you over a misunderstanding.

Whether you’re a returning player from
Black Flag or someone entirely new with
no knowledge of the series, Freedom Cry’s
story is the main draw of the game, being
simple, accessable and without any obvious
baggage from the previous games.

Freedom Cry’s cast is limited to revolving
around only four characters; Adewale himself,
his person-of-interest; the beautiful Bastienne
Josephe, the local Madame of the Brothel in
Port-Au-Prince, the evil Governeur De Fayet
and the stoic Augustin Dieufort, leader of the
Maroon Rebellion.

Most of Assassin’s Creed: Black Flag is on
display at its finest here. The activities like
whaling for animal skins and crafting materials
return in a smaller capacity, the naval combat
and free-running are top-notch as ever and
the graphics can bring an underequipped
PC to ruin.

You find yourself giggling as you see your idiot
boss in the villainous Governeur De Fayet, and
you relish how satisfying it is to go around
freeing your brothers in chains while you kill
Slavers and soldiers who oppress and bully.

Each mission or small side-quest you complete
brings you closer to the real-world, so you can
resume your responsibilities without the urge to
take a machete into your boss’s face or kill your
classmates for not doing enough in your group
projects.

Freedom Cry’s ending makes you pick up
the phone to apologize to _Summer-Rain_.
She asks what brought about this change of
heart. You tell her about Freedom Cry.

How you bought a game of prejudice, which
was also with a means to fight it and the effort
it came with to fight such things like prejudice,
racism and slavery.

How you bought newfound gratitude for your
life and things you have. The things you took
for granted, and the things you had taken for
granted.

The people you had taken for granted.

She responds, dabbing her eyes.
“Let’s not fight... Not when we can play
games like the one you just finished.”

You answer while smiling on the other end.
“You’re right, Summer. Let Freedom Cry.”

reviewText:
Freedom Cry is a bit of stand-alone DLC for AC4. You play as Adewale, your ship Quartermaster from AC4 turned Assassin. Who sets out on a quest of his own to liberate slaves in the Carribean.

Freedom Cry does a lot to try and be different than AC4. For starters the game is more stealth focused. For much of the game you're liberating slaves from plantations by eliminating their overseers. And the player gets rewarded with new tools, upgrades and weapons for freeing more slaves. However if the player caught they begin to murder the slaves before you can free them. This creates an incentive to play as stealthily as possible and as a result there's significantly less of a combat focus. This was clearly intentional and you tend to only use your blowgun and hidden blades.

As a result Freedom Cry feels significantly more like a stealth action game than any of the previous Assassin Creed games. And it's to it's credit. The only real gripes I have with it are the story is a bit lacking compared to AC4 and it doesn't take you that long to complete. It is priced pretty reasonably though and it's a blast to try and complete 100%.

I highly recommend Freedom Cry. It complements AC4 nicely, and its more focused stealth gameplay is a welcome change.

reviewText:
I was compelled to try 'Assassin's Creed Freedom Cry' after learning that slavery is the primary theme of the game. It is a game full of potential -- beautiful graphics, excellent voice acting, and a seldomly explored subject matter tied together with a commercially proven gaming formula. Yet, while 'Freedom Cry' was not horrible, it was not stellar or impressive as it should be. What we got is a game with a partially developed character, about whom I actually want to learn more, in a half-baked story that felt like 'Assassin's Creed' Lite.

It was innovative to play as a slave-turned-Assassin, who despite having gifts and talents bestowed upon him by the Brotherhood, still needed to be weary of slave jailers because of the colour of his skin. This was enough to change the usual pace of an 'Assassin's Creed' game, and I quite enjoyed that. Not needing to deal with modern day Abstergo/Animus story elements was also very welcomed, but it was odd to see the concept of synchronicity being left in the game. The modern day story elements in 'Assassin's Creed' had always felt like Ubisoft lacked confidence in a loosely historical third-person stealth action game. 'Freedom Cry' would have been the perfect opportunity for the franchise to distant itself from this extraneous story element, but that chance was unfortunately wasted.

My biggest complaint about 'Freedom Cry', is the naval combat. As someone who had not played 'Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag', I found the learning curve for naval warfare to be steep. There wasn't much of a tutorial and it took much trial and error for me to fully understand the basic mechanics. Plus, there was one mission that would have been difficulty to complete if I had not fully upgraded my ship through constant pirating. Such level grinding has no place in a game like 'Freedom Cry' as it slowed the entire game down. That and the repetitiveness and general lack of mission variety made the game rather tedious at times. Seriously, how many eavesdropping missions did 'Freedom Cry' really need for a nine-mission game?

The theme of slavery is both a shining factor and a major weakness of 'Freedom Cry'. I got much satisfaction freeing slaves in the game, but when the number of slaves I freed became the currency of weapon upgrades eligibility, I became frustrated. Shouldn't I be freeing slaves because it is the right thing to do and because it is the main character's motivation, not because of a weapon upgrade? Plus, why would black merchants, who knew I free slaves, only sell me weapons if I meet a quota? This game mechanic, while thematically important, was not very well thought out and well implemented.

For those who have played 'Black Flag', 'Freedom Cry' may appeal to you, but for those who haven't, your time may be better spent on other games than this somewhat mediocre entry to the 'Assassin's Creed' franchise.

Freedom Cry is the main DLC content for Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag and follows the efforts of Adewale, Edward Kenway's former quartermaster and now an Assassin, to aid the Maroon slaves rebellion around the town of Port'au'Prince.
Compared to the main game, Freedom Cry's main novelity as a DLC are the liberation side quest, which involves completing random events around the map in order to free slaves and obtain more rebels on the protagonist's side. Clearing these events becomes mandatory later on due to some main missions being unlocked only after a certain quota of slaves has been achieved. There are also some plantations the player can raid to further boost the rebels rank.
Aside from these events, Freedom Cry doesn't offer much new content or mechanics, fancing itself as just a smaller version of Black Flag which can be cleared in under four hours. It's also worth mentioning that the naval features are barely used in the DLC at all, due to the far smaller overall map and the main missions taking place mainly in Port'au'Prince.
What makes Freedom Cry worth a shot from any player from the Assassin's Creed series is the compelling story, which sets it quite apart from Edward's adventure and manages to be both engaging and rather touching

reviewText:
Presentation
Freedom Cry tells the story of Black Flag's Adéwalé, twenty years after the story of Edward Kenway, following Adéwalé in his journey through the West Indies Sea, where he ends up shipwrecked on the coast of Haiti. Making his way into Port-au-Prince he meets up with Bastienne Josèphe, the proprietor of a local brothel and a sympathiser to the Maroons, a faction of freedom fighters made up of liberated slaves. Soon afterwards Adéwalé gets caught up in the events and ends up teaming with the Maroons to free slaves from around the West Indies Sea. As emotional and personal the story is, its length demolishes almost everything the plot wants to uncover, as most missions will be over before you realize it, leaving details aside and focusing only on the main objectives, therefore taking away from the emotional impact the story could've had if we were presented with some background on the slaves and their masters which Adéwalé is supposed to fight blindly. Adéwalé's relationship with Bastienne Josèphe is one of the few things that stands out strong throughout the six hour adventure, as you will find out more about her intentions from one visit to the next one, and by the end of the story form a bond with her that you could only wish would continue for a few more hours.
Rating: 6.5

Gameplay
Being an extension to Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag, Freedom Cry plays exactly the same, with a few interesting things added for the best, and a lot of amazing features present in the original game removed for the worst. This is still an open world game, so you can use your ship to travel from one location to another just like you did in Black Flag, but not only is the game limited to the West Indies Sea which is a pretty small portion of the Caribbean, but at the same time that portion feels empty in a way that Black Flag never did, even with its enormous map. There are only three main islands where the main plot will take you and maybe five more where you can find a chest or a secret, but for the most part the seas feel empty, and even in those main islands aside from the objective where the mission takes you and the slave liberation missions there is nothing else to do, something that feels weird to begin with for an Assassin's Creed game. On the bright side, the Blunderbuss and Adéwalé's machete are some great new tools to play around with, at least in the main missions since that's the only occasion you'll get to use them properly.
Rating: 6

Graphics
Freedom Cry was built as an extension to Black Flag, so it uses the same engine and environment, which is only for the best since the original game was a beauty with vast seas, populated lands and unforgiving fleets. In this title, the seas are still there in all their beauty and so are the ships cruising them, but the difference comes when you set sail for land and realize there is nothing else to see there; unlike Black Flag, Freedom Cry has only a few island and even those look similar, as no matter which one you set foot on next, you'll still be greeted by the same slave plantation or empty beach.
Rating: 6.5

Audio
With such great audio design and quality in Black Flag, it was impossible to screw it up this time, since most of it is reused in here, which isn't much of a problem since all the effects feel authentic in Adéwalé's story as well. There are a couple new tunes created for Freedom Cry exclusively and those find their spot in Adéwalé's story flawlessly, and thanks to some great voice acting performed by Tristan D. Lalla, Adéwalé's character feels even more authentic than it did before in Black Flag throughout Kenway's story.
Rating: 9.5

Extras
Even though this can be purchased as a standalone experience, it is obviously just an extension to Black Flag, but even so playing an Assassin's Creed game where you can barely squeeze six hours of playtime if you're taking your time with the story, completing all the slave liberation missions and looking around for the few islands that hide a chest feels weird since Assassin's Creed was always about exploration and the things you can do on the side, things that are almost non-existent in Freedom Cry.
Rating: 5.5

Verdict
Freedom Cry wanted to tell a more personal story than the original Black Flag, but unfortunately the limited length of the story, as well as the empty environment in which it takes place makes it fall flawed as important and emotional events will be over before realizing it and for most parts without any explanation or background on Adéwalé's intentions.
Rating Overall: 6.8

This review is for those who actually have played Assassins Creed Black Flag. If you do not have it I suggest you buy it at a sale because the main game will be cheaper than the dlc since the price is only slightly higher but the overall content is more aswell.

I own Assassins Creed on XBox 360 and the game simply is breathtaking with the easy to learn gameplay, the open world features and the good and atmospheric music. However it took me about 20 Hours to discover all the places unlock everything and tried the minigames like fishing. (They are the same as in Black Flag though)

Adewale has his own combat style and uses a machete. Like Kennway he can use firearms, ropedarts, poisoned darts etc. The overall gameplay is the same as in Black Flag but the story is set 20 years later. (I wont say much about it since i dont want to spoiler and it depends on your taste if you will enjoy it or not).

The map is not very big, i am guessing less than 25% of Black Flags overall map but the locations have their own appearance and are detailed.

I did not encounter any notable bugs but I was a bit dissappointed that Adewales ship is a repainted Jackdaw.
The ship however cannot be upgraded as much as the Jackdaw.

A new element in the game is as already mentioned Adewales own combat style and the ability to free slaves either by boarding slave ships or by killing the overseers at the plantations. Some of the overseers have become very hostile and will attack you instantly. If you are spotted on the plantations, the overseers are going to kill your maroonfellows so you should really take care.
The plantations sooner or later always get new owners so you can replay this part. The game also can be continued after the story has come to an end just like in Black Flag.

If you enjoyed Black Flag and want some more story related content or discover some more West Indies locations I really recommend this but dont expect a lot of new content. Also keep an eye out for a decent sale, I suggest maybe 3-5 dollars is a good price.

reviewText:
If you've beaten Black Flag and want more, this will mostly do the trick. Set 13-15 years after AC4, Adewale has risen from Kenway's right-hand man, to a full-fledged Assassin/Captain. After an intense opening scene, he finds himself washed ashore and caught in the midst of a civil struggle. It's time to free some slaves, hence the subtitle of the game. There are many different scenarios in which you can free said slaves. Some will be locked in a cage, and you have to kill the guard carrying the key. Others will be working on plantations, in which you must eliminate a certain number of guards to free them.

Freeing as many slaves as possible actually grants you bonuses, and sometimes even needed to advance the story. The bonuses range from free restocks on ammunition, to even new weapons. With slaves pratically all over the place ready to be liberated, achieving these bonuses doesn't exactly take a long time.

As you'd expect, Freedom Cry does have naval content, including it's own (DLC sized) open-world map. Attacking and boarding other ships for goods is still relevant, but nowhere near as much as Black Flag. A lot of the locations to discover are unfortunately pretty dull. There's several islands which consist of only a small beach and one chest to open, then you're done there. I'm not sure why Ubisoft even bothered, as it's probably the most disappointing part of FC. Still, just sailing the open sea remains a joy to behold. No sea shanties (pirate songs), however.

Just like Black Flag, Freedom Cry is GORGEOUS. It's a shame that sometimes some information is still present on your screen, even with the HUD options turned all off"

reviewText:
TLDR: A sloppy and underwhelming DLC product that does a disservice to both it's subject matter and original game. Buy the base game, Assassins Creed 4: Black Flag, or Assassins Creed: Rogue.

The narrative feels rushed and unfocused, beginning and ending rather abruptly. It starts with your classic AC MacGuffin, then promptly forgets about it; Then touches on themes of slavery but begins to quickly move them to the backround, instead focusing too much of it's narrative on a cartographer mapping the Caribbean that happens to be in Port au Prince (The primary setting of this DLC.) This leads to far too many tail/eavesdrop missions, moreso some of the worst, most frustrating examples in any of the AC games to date. It relies too much on tightly scripted sequences that limit your mobility and/or abilities and mistakes tedium for engagement too often. The main story missions can be completed in under 4 hours.

The freeing of slaves is relegated mostly to narrative-devoid side activities, tied to unlocking upgraded weapons and other optional items, cheapening the poignancy to the point of repetitively farming a statistic. The repetition is not helped by the rapid respawn of prisoners; I could return to the same spot within two minutes to find new caged prisoners, new guards taking the exact same routes, the corpses of their predecessors still laying about.

The game is really at it's best when you are raiding plantations. You free the slaves of the plantation by killing guards. It's just nice having that chance to take it on in your own way, with your full set of skills and the space to use them instead of limiting them like a majority of the main missions. It's always the same objective, Kill 20 guards, and it feels like a wasted opportunity; It could have used more variety to keep it fresh, and without narrative it only serves as a distraction from the underwhelming storyline.

Sailing feels like an afterthought, with a very small map and only a handful of locations to explore, with many of those being little more than beaches with a chest or two on them. After all the sea shanties of AC4, it is very noticeable that Adewale's ship crew is generally silent; it would have been nice if there were a couple of new, theme appropriate songs for them to sing, or just a few of the old ones. There are no treasure maps to find, no forts to destroy, no side assassinations to undertake. Hunting and whaling are pointless as there's nothing to craft. I didn't even notice there were ship upgrades until the second playthrough, the ship's upgraded enough out of the gate to deal with the few ship-to-ship fights. It's also painfully obvious you're always sailing the Jackdaw, the recycled ship model from the main game (AC4 Black Flag.) The ship you're sailing and sinks out of the gate is identical, and then the next one you steal is EXACTLY THE SAME, right down to the decorations, even the three skulls hanging over captains quarters entrance.

The new items border on impractical: The blunderbuss is a shrapnel-spread shotgun that's just as likely to kill the slaves you're trying to free or your crew as you board other ships; The noise-making firecrackers can only be dropped right in front of you and the noise doesn't seem to have much distance. The Machete is a sword, just like any other AC game, albeit with some pretty sweet, brutal animations. The animations are sort of aesthetically flawed since they go on a little long in combos and tend to get cut off as you parry other enemies in groups.

As with other recent series entries, this one suffers from an inconsistent frame rate and animation/scripting bugs that mar it's presentation. I watched a hunter's ship sail up the side of an islands rocky peak and into the air before flipping back into the water. I was caught during tailing/eavesdrop missions because sometimes the target would get caught on something/someone and would do a quick spin on the spot, seeing in all directions at once for a second. Sometimes freeing slaves would spawn guards out of thin air (Maybe not a bug but it happened a lot, it was tedious and annoying.) The frame rate plummets noticeably at seemingly random intervals and occasionally assets will materialise in front of Adewale as he runs through the streets.

Adewale is a potentially interesting and charismatic character and I was hoping to get to know him a bit better, as well as explore a very dark aspect of colonialism that was largely glossed over in AC 3 and 4. Freedom Cry does little to add much dimension to it's protagonist, seems uncomfortable confronting the issues of it's own subject matter, and it's disappointing it failed to approach it with compelling narrative or engaging gameplay.

Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag: Freedom Cry Standalone game review:

In this Assassin's Creed game you are Adewale, a big black dude with a machete and a blunderbuss (Big shotgunny thing). You were formerly a slave, working on a plantation until pirates raided it. Although Adewale was previously the legendary Edward Kenway's Quartermaster, Adewale found that he wanted to save slaves, rather than be a pirate. In this game, you follow him across the Carribean, as he liberates slaves and recruits maroons.

The quality of the game is FANTASTIC! A new feature for the AC series (which was also introduced in Black Flag) is sailing across open world areas, rather than only whilst on missions (in Assassin's Creed 3). Sailing is incredibly simple as all you do is press the forward key, maybe move left and right, etc. A feature of the game (which personally had me excited) was the ability to board other enemy vessels. Boarding too is simple. All you do is press the S key (or whatever you have set stop to) whilst alongside another almost destroyed vessel, and it will automatically cause your ship to dock alongside. Your crew too will react, throwing Grappling hooks to draw your vessels nearer to each other.Your crew will then board the vessel and so on. The Graphics in the game are of a high standard, as Nvidia is involved (seeing as modern Nvidia games are awesome), so you will need at least a 2.6 GHZ processor and a decent graphics card to withstand the urges ingame. The fighting style in AC4 is incredibly similar to that of AC3, with only a couple of differences. For £11 I am incredibly happy, aand will be getting Black Flag soon.

reviewText:
Freedom Cry has its problems (which I'll get into here in a bit) and it doesn't really do much for the overarching narrative of the series as a whole, but it's still fun to play.

You play as Adewale, member of the Assassins and Edward Kenway's former quartermaster. You begin on the seas in your ship on a mission to intercept a Templar package.  After a brief naval battle, you sail through a storm and end up in Port au Prince in Sam Domingue. From there onwards, you do all kinds of Assassin-y stuff on your own personal mission (of sorts) to free slaves and uncover a plot by Pierre, marquis de Fayet to...do stuff.

Freedom Cry doesn't really offer anything new that Black Flag didn't. In fact, a bit less, which makes sense when you consider the fact that it was originally just a DLC pack before it became a standalone game. Oh and they weren't kidding when they said standalone. If you've never played a single Assassin's Creed title before this one, you won't have any problems grasping what's going on, as it really doesn't have anything to do with the main plot of the series. But, I digress.

You get two main weapons: a machete and a blunderbuss (as well as your hidden blades, but hidden blades in Assassin's Creed are a given at this point). Both can be upgraded with different versions, but still, the lack of variety in weapon types is a little disappointing. But, again, it's DLC. Most of the side weapons from Black Flag are present, including the blow gun and the rope dart.

The naval combat is as excellent as ever, though if you haven't played Black Flag it may take a little while to grasp as there's no real tutorial for it here. Your ship, the Experto Crede, is slightly upgradeable with a few gun and mortar upgrades, as well as a hull upgrade. You can also (kind of) customize its appearance with some nifty anti-slavery decorations.

Very basically, it's a slightly stripped-down Black Flag with a different main character and a much shorter storyline. Very fun to play, frustrating as hell at times, and (SLIGHT SPOILER ALERT THINLY VEILED IN RIDDLE) it'll leave you feeling a bit like Brad Pitt's character at the end of Seven. Remember Seven? Man, that was a good movie. What? Oh, right. The review. Um, yeah. Play this game. And stuff.

reviewText:
While I cannot atest to the quality of Assassin's Creed IV, III was an utter mess. Glitchy, buggy, time-wasting and otherwise lost in the sea of AAA checkpoints just to make a sale; Connor deserved a much better game surrounding his wonderfully built world.

This seemed to be the trend with a lot of Ubisoft titles as of late. Stuff the world full of as much nonsense as you can and hope the players get distracted to ignore the flaws. It didn't work in the case of Assassin's Creed III and I have no idea how much superfluous extras there are in IV. With this standalone campaign, though, Ubisoft have finally nailed a perfect balance of missions and pacing.

No longer do you need to trek through mindless set ups and investigations to get to the good stuff. Freedom Cry almost sticks to action 100% of the time, but you do get some small diversions to break up the monotony. Forcing side missions on the player isn't that nice, but the missions are given some extra weight due to the setting and narrative.

As for the plotline, I can't say that I was impressed. I love the idea of a former slave joining the creed and exacting vengeance, but I think IV had more setup for main character, Adewale, that is missing from this. Even the beginning of the game seems like it was already underway before my intervention.

The game also does succumb to being a bit scripted. One of the later missions on a sinking ship would have been exhilerating if there were some actual danger involved. Instead, you simply can wait around until the game tells you to leave and be done with it. Smoke and mirrors was the name of the game with III and I'm sad to see it still being utilized here.

There are also the occassional problems with pathfinding while running and combat getting lost with the camera. I often couldn't tell what I was doing or had a hard time stopping myself from performing one action and ended up failing missions. It can be aggravating when you fail due to no fault of your own, but the extremely generous checkpoints make nearly every mistake moot.

The game is also exceptionally easy. I messed up in a few parts with naval battles, but that was mostly because of my lack of experience with them (I know IV is based around naval encounters). The ship mechanics are vastly improved from III and are actually quite enjoyable. I wouldn't mind getting into more of them.

So overall, Freedom Cry is a nice little diversion from the normal Assassin's Creed experience. It's short length makes it great to plow through in one sitting. It's also a lot more consistent in quality and mission structure than III could ever hope to be.

While it may feel a little undercooked, it still rings true as a beacon of fresh air within this franchise. Hopefully Ubisoft realizes that jamming your game with extraneous missions isn't the best way to garner value for your title.

7/10

I love the idea of a former slave joining the creed and exacting vengeance, but I think IV had more setup for main character, Adewale, that is missing from this. Even the beginning of the game seems like it was already underway before my intervention.

The game also does succumb to being a bit scripted. One of the later missions on a sinking ship would have been exhilerating if there were some actual danger involved. Instead, you simply can wait around until the game tells you to leave and be done with it. Smoke and mirrors was the name of the game with III and I'm sad to see it still being utilized here.

There are also the occassional problems with pathfinding while running and combat getting lost with the camera. I often couldn't tell what I was doing or had a hard time stopping myself from performing one action and ended up failing missions. It can be aggravating when you fail due to no fault of your own, but the extremely generous checkpoints make nearly every mistake moot.

The game is also exceptionally easy. I messed up in a few parts with naval battles, but that was mostly because of my lack of experience with them (I know IV is based around naval encounters). The ship mechanics are vastly improved from III and are actually quite enjoyable. I wouldn't mind getting into more of them.

So overall, Freedom Cry is a nice little diversion from the normal Assassin's Creed experience. It's short length makes it great to plow through in one sitting. It's also a lot more consistent in quality and mission structure than III could ever hope to be.

While it may feel a little undercooked, it still rings true as a beacon of fresh air within this franchise. Hopefully Ubisoft realizes that jamming your game with extraneous missions isn't the best way to garner value for your title.

reviewText:
This trumped – down, Black Flag spin – off can easily be described in four words: Pure, unadulterated, machete mayhem. Freedom Cry suffers from the same issues that all these little filler titles in the series face. It is small in scale, meaning that from the grandiose Black Flag Caribbean, you now get to basically explore a rather small Port-au-Prince, some plantations and beaches and a single wreck. It is less polished, with a fast and easy story whose completion comes rather swiftly and without much diversity. Lastly, the characters don’t give off the same attraction as in the main titles of the series.

The above is not to say that Freedom Cry doesn’t have its good aspects. The weapon and upgrade acquisition mechanics have been simplified, to the extent where they liberate the player from grinding money to acquire a new weapon or a ship upgrade, taking a menial task of a player’s shoulders and allowing for more slave – freeing. Which, slave – freeing, is done with ample use of your machete and blunderbuss, adding to this loose yet deadly feeling of the title. There is a liberating feeling on just hacking and scatter-shooting your way through the streets, while at the same time freeing the unfortunate slaves paraded about. Adewale is also pretty cool as a character, though he lacks an adequate support cast.

The controls are the same as in Black Flag, so if you’ve been there, you can jump right in here. There is also some nice music and signing, appropriate for the culture of the people ferried in as slaves to the plantations, which gives a nice feeling of change to the previously known Europe-based musical scores. The game remains definitively easy though, with almost nothing to offer in terms of difficulty, challenge and replayability.

Freedom Cry is by no means a bad game. It is just too small and limited in scope for me to be able to recommend it as a purchase to someone, as not playing it doesn’t really deprive you of anything.

Let's just get to the point.

First off, I liked the game. I had fun playing it. Adewale is so cool, he was born a slave and escaped to become an assassin. Now he's coming back to the carribian as captain of his own ship to end slavery in Port au Prince. Adewale, like all the characters in this game, is a very strong and interesting character. The story, however short, is well written, suspenseful, and griping. You also get to steer your own ship and engage in fights oversea.

These are all the things I enjoyed about the game. But here's where the game falters.

The first thing I'd like to point out is how very poorly optimized the game is; in every meaning of the phrase. The graphics are beautiful, but if you have them turned up as high as the they can go, the game runs as slowly as a stop-motion animation film. (and I don't mean slower THAN a stop-motion film, I mean slower than MAKING a stop-motion film.) to get the game to run on a playable level, I had to either put all settings as low as they could go, or completely turn off everything. (and I do mean everything) This was the first time I ever had to play a game windowized. The only thing I could play with, was the Vsync.

This game was my introducion into the assasin's creed universe. So I had absolutely no experience with how to use my weapons, perform parkour, or really interact with anything. The game has no tutorial. I just trial and errored my way through, and after two hours of playing, running, climbing, ship piloting, and purposely getting into fights just to read all of the options that flashed before my face, I had about an 80% understanding of how to control my character and how to pilot my ship.

In addition to this, the controls are just... weird. This game was meant to be played on Xbox, with an Xbox controler. But I don't have an Xbox, so I just use my keyboard. The keyboard and mouse controls do what they're supposed to do most of the time, but sometimes, they cause your character to do things that you didn't tell them to do. I once tried to run up behind two people and double assassinate them, but no matter how much I clicked, my character just ran right past the guys, right in front of their faces. Those guys then sounded the alarm, and beofre I knew it, I was in a fight with 10 guys. and speaking of which...

The combat. I managed to win that fight with the ten guys. Most of the time when gaurds attack me, only one attacks at a time, and the rest just stand around waiting for me to defeat their friend before jumping in one at a time. I've been able to easily defeat an entire ship of guys by myself. And not because I'm skilled, but because my opponents just really don't seem to know what they're doing. (how did these guys become drafted in the military?)

Ship piloting: Again, a tutorial on how to fire my mortars; as well as my fire barrels; and how to use my swivel cannons, would have been very useful.

Overall, combat feels unengaging and boring. When I'm playing the game I don't feel like I have complete control over my characters actions, which is also unengaging. It kinda sucks having to play a game that has a reputation for good graphics, yet I have to turn them all down to make it playable.

Overall, I wouldn't reccomend this. Not on Steam anyway. Assassin's Creed is made for Xbox and meant to be played on Xbox. So if you want it, get it on Xbox. Not on Steam.

reviewText:
Assassin’s Creed Freedom Cry is a standalone game that follows the same pattern as its predecessor did, Black Flag, but this time the main protagonist was a secondary character on the previous title, Adéwalé, being an assassin and many years after the ending of Black Flag, we found ourselves stranded on Port-au-Prince, with no ship and no crew, we must struggle to find our way out of there, though now his motivations are focused on the liberation of slaves that suffer greatly in the new world.

Story
1735 is the year and Adéwalé is now an Assassin, embracing the creed’s beliefs and struggle, he finds himself stranded in Port-au-Prince. But after many years of piracy he decides now is time to put the Creed’s name to a good use and begin a new fight and the liberation of slaves, helping the resistance called The Maroons for independence and dignity, Adéwalé and his skills turn out to be of great help to the resistance. Before leaving, he helps building a new hope for the slaves.

Gameplay
The game mechanics don’t change that much compared to Black Flag, though some new load-out for a new assassin is required as per usual, for Adéwalé we have now some powerful weapons like the blunderbuss and machete, while the blunderbuss is a one-shot gun, its power doesn’t have match, it is a slow weapon but once you have multiple enemies facing you, one blow will kill most of them, if not all, making it a death fest every time you pull the trigger.

On the other hand, the machete is kind of new to us, we have mostly used swords before, but Adéwalé with machete in hand makes him, perhaps the most brutal and relentless fighter of all assassins in my opinion, he is just a beast and the killing animations are proof of it, a good tool for a great and skilled killer.

Many other things remain the same, there are not many differences, smoke bombs, the rope dart and the poison and sleep darts are kept, a small addition were the firecrackers that will help you with guards at some point in the story, besides that, the game remains almost the same.

Naval combat is the same as well, and the map is very limited, but makes sense, this game is not that long and the exploration is restricted to some few islands and locations.

The interesting part of this game is and will always be slavery, our struggle is focused on the liberation of slaves, there are plantations in different parts of the map which can be raided and liberated, this will help you unlock new items and missions and also bring new people to the resistance, also during naval combat you will encounter enemy ships carrying many ore slaves, this ships cannot be attacked but they will always have protection. In the main city, small groups of slaves can be liberated as well, either from punishment, caging or auctions.

Graphics
There are not many things to say on this point, it looks the same as Black Flag, equally beautiful, so if you want to know more, read my Black Flag review.

Sound and music
The sound remains identical to Black Flag as well, voices are full of passion and the accents are great. On the music side, we have some new sounds and tunes that are related to the culture, some sort of African like melodies with chants in French, this makes the atmosphere of the game and the slavery theme. Awesome.

The bad
While ACFC remains bug free and found no issues in-game, I really believe that some few things could have been different to my taste. For example, after liberating plantations, a good idea would have been to destroy at some point certain plantations, setting them on fire or destroying the crops, making them a waste of time to rebuild, this came to my mind after seeing how many times x plantation had a new owner after a few minutes, making it an endless loop of liberation, makes sense, yes, slaves were a profitable business back then and at some point someone will bring more and more, but stopping them once and for all would have been more satisfying in the end.

Final words
ACFC is a good game on its own, it doesn’t have the same spectrum as previous titles and the character is not developed in depth, but that is not a problem when it comes to action and the brutal way we kill enemies. There are some scenes that truly show how slavery was back in that time, it was terrible and at some point you can see how the life of the slaves was regarded as disposable by the masters and the empires. There are heartbreaking moments to say the least.

All in all, it was an enjoyable game, with more pros than cons, new tools and weapons and a very satisfying gameplay, Adéwalé is a killing machine!
